stories.title: A Kabul-based crisis alert app struggles to protect its own employees
What is it like to have a photographic memory?

stories.text:
We have IoT sensor data currently flowing Raspberry Pi → Telegraf → InfluxDB → Grafana (TIG stack). This is fine for simple queries and visualization. I'd like to move to a more proper data infrastructure for 1) SQL-based analytics, 2) pub-sub e.g. MQTT (to decouple sources from sinks), and 3) long-term storage. But we want to keep using Grafana.

We're talking on the order of tens/hundreds of devices posting data every 1 min or so, not petabytes.

Should I be following a data lake architecture and doing MQTT → S3 / Redshift → ??? → PostgreSQL → Grafana? That seems like a lot of work / maintenance / overkill (?).

Or skip S3 / Redshift and just write a custom MQTT → PostgreSQL bridge? (Why isn't there an off-the-shelf solution, or am I missing something? I feel like this must be a common problem?)

Or should I be looking more at enterprise services e.g. Snowflake?

Known constraints: • Grafana supports PostgreSQL as a data source (but not Amazon Redshift). • Kinesis Firehose supports S3 and Redshift as destinations (but not RDS / PostgreSQL). • Telegraf doesn't (officially) support PostgreSQL as an output.

I am not a data engineer and want to avoid being one :)
